Some of the earliest forms of democratic government in Europe include:

1. The Ancient Athenian democracy: The Athenian democracy, which began in the 6th century BC, was one of the earliest known systems of direct democracy in Europe. Citizens had the right to vote on laws and hold public office.

2. The Roman Republic: The Roman Republic, which was established in 509 BC, was a government system that relied on the election of officials to represent the people. The Senate, made up of elected representatives, served as the main governing body.

3. The Swiss Confederation: The Swiss Confederation, which began in the 13th century, was one of the earliest federal systems of government in Europe. The cantons, or states, had a high degree of autonomy and the federal government was comprised of elected representatives.

4. The Dutch Republic: The Dutch Republic, which emerged in the 16th century, was a representative democracy where citizens could vote for representatives who would then form the government.

5. The English Civil War: The English Civil War, which took place in the 17th century, resulted in the establishment of a constitutional monarchy with a system of representative government. The Bill of Rights, passed in 1689, established many of the rights and freedoms that are still in place in modern democracies.
